p: In tropical Southeast Asia, the five morphologically closely related species of the Albopictus subgroup live in forests ( Aedes novalbopictus, Aedes patriciae, Aedes seatoi, Aedes subalbopictus and Aedes pseudalbopictus) and lay their eggs in tree holes and bamboo stumps [ 39, 40]. These species are likely to be vectors of arboviruses to vertebrates from which they take blood. These forest-confined viruses are largely unknown, but may emerge through increased contact with humans or domestic animals (see below). They could then be transmitted by domestic vectors, such as Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus, in a pattern similar to the emergence of the yellow fever virus in Africa from forests to villages [ 12].
